hive_lesson.title: 01 Verb (Be)
hive_lesson.description: Learn about the teacher and the site.

hive_text_custom.text: : So Todd, where are you from?
: I am from the U.S., I am from San Francisco. It's on the west coast.
: I'm an English teacher. Also, I create Elllo. I work on Elllo a lot.
: I am 47. Yeah. I am old.
: No. That's not old. Who is your best friend?
: My best friend is Don, he is a teacher too. He lives in America.
: No, I am not married. I am still single.
: My mom is from California, she is from Los Angeles.
: She is a manager, she works in a clothing store.
: My dad is from San Francisco. He is not from Los Angeles, but he met my mother in Los Angeles.
: He is also a manager, he works for a tree cutting company. They cut trees.
: It is, a little dangerous. A little.							   And Aimee, what about you? Where are you from?
: I'm from Glasgow, on the west coast of Scotland in the United Kingdom.
: Nice. And what do you do?
: It is. It is very fun. Excuse me, can I ask, how old are you?
: Of course, you can ask. I'm 34.
: Okay. Very young. Very young. Where is your mom from?
: My mum is also from Glasgow.
: Oh, nice. What does she do?
: Well, she's retired now, but she was a nurse.
: Oh nice. And is your dad from Glasgow?
: He's also retired, but he used to be a teacher.
: Well, thanks Aimee. Nice talking to you.

hive_lesson_quiz.question: 1) Where is he from?
2) How old is he?
3) Where is she from?
4) Who is a teacher?

hive_lesson_grammar.title: Be Verbs (am, is, are) Simple Present

hive_grammar.point: Point 1: The Be verb has three forms in the present tense - am, is, are.
Point 2: Use am and am not for the pronoun I.
Point 3: Use are and are not for the pronoun you.
Point 4: Use is and is not for the pronoun she.
Point 5: Use is and is not for the pronoun he.
Point 6: Use is and is not for the pronoun it.
Point 7: Use are and are not for the pronoun they.

hive_text_custom.text: They're not my shoes. (are not = 're not)
They aren't my shoes. (are not = aren't)

hive_grammar.point: Point 8: Use are and are not for the pronoun we.

hive_text_custom.text: : Natalie, let's talk about our favorite things.
: First, what is your favorite color?
: Really? My favorite color is purple too.
: Yeah, but I don't have purple clothing. I love the color purple, but I don't have purple clothes.
: Oh, well, everything I wear is purple.
: That's so cool. So what about food? What's your favorite food?
: Good question. My favorite food is pizza. I love pizza, but I don't like really big pizzas.
: I love pizza too. What is your favorite topping on pizza?
: I like really spicy toppings, so salami or pepperoni, chilies, and sometimes bell peppers too.
: Do you like thick pizza or thin pizza?
: No, I don't like thick pizza, because I can't eat too much. The thin pizzas, I get lots of toppings and I don't feel so full.
: Yeah, I agree. What about seasons? What is your favorite season?
: Yeah, I love winter, don't you?
: No, I hate winter. Why do you like winter?
: Oh, I hate the snow. Well, I like the snow a little bit, but I hate cold weather.
: Yeah, I guess the cold is kind of annoying, but the snow is so much fun. I go skiing and I play snowball fights and I build snowmen.
: Yeah, that sounds fun. What about sports? What's your favorite sport?
: I'd say my favorite sport is tennis.
: That's interesting. Do you play tennis?
: Yeah, but I'm not very good.
: Do you like singles or doubles?
: At the moment I'm having singles lessons. They're really fun.
: Oh, now you are taking tennis lessons?
: Do you watch tennis on TV?
: Yes, I watch it all the time.
: Who is your favorite tennis player?
: Yeah. He's really good. Okay, last question. What is your favorite movie?
: I don't have a favorite movie, but I really like comedies.
: So what is your favorite comedy?
: My favorite comedy is Ace Ventura.
: Ace Ventura is very funny, but that movie is really old.
: It is, but it's a classic, Todd.
: It's like 20 years old, I think, maybe more.
: I know. I've seen it a hundred times.
: Yeah. I like it a lot too.

hive_lesson_quiz.question: 1) What is purple?
2) What does she like on her pizza?
3) What does she like about winter?
4) What does she say about tennis?
5) What kind of movie does she like?

hive_vocab.examples:
What foods do you like?
I like pizza.
I don't like pineapple.

What fruits do you like?
I love waternelon.
I hate oranges.

What is your favorite color?
 
My favorite color is blue.
I don't like grey.

Do you like green vegetables?
 
Yeah, I do. (Yes = Yeah)
No, not really.

hive_lesson.title: 03 Basic Verbs
hive_lesson.description: Two people discuss their weekend routines.

hive_text_custom.text: : Hey, Shantel, what do you do on the weekend?
: On the weekend, I wake up and, first, I make breakfast.
: All right. I often eat toast, too.
: Do you put butter on your toast?
: I do. I put butter and jam.
: Ew, I love butter and jam on my toast.
: No. I used to, but not anymore.
: On the weekend, I don't eat cereal. On the weekend, I cook a nice breakfast, but I eat cereal during the week. What else do you do on the weekend?
: Let's see. After I eat breakfast, I clean the kitchen and make my bed. What about you?
: I also clean my house. I clean my rooms. I vacuum. I wash the windows. I wash the dishes. I do my laundry. I do that on Saturday, but on Sunday, I have fun.
: What do you do for fun?

: I go to the park. I play sports. I play soccer at the park. Sometimes, I ride my bike. Sometimes, I go hiking. I do lots on Sunday. On Sunday, I relax. I don't study. I don't work, and I don't clean my house.
: What do you do on Sunday?
: I also enjoy my time on Sunday. I really like to meet my friends and, sometimes, we go to festivals or visit new cities, and we eat a lot of really good food.
: Actually, we also really enjoy camping. Do you like camping?
: I love camping. I love the outdoors. I go hiking often.
: Oh, that's cool. What about Sunday evening?
: Oh, Sunday evening, I relax. I cook a big dinner, and I listen to music, and, sometimes, I read my book, but, often, I go to sleep very early on Sunday.

: Well, on Sunday, I don't cook. I usually order food. I order pizza or maybe I eat at a restaurant, and then, later in the evening, on Sunday, I always watch TV. My favorite TV show is on Sunday night.
: My favorite TV show is called Billions.
: Yeah. It's about money and power in New York. It's very interesting.
:  Nice. Maybe I should watch it.
: Oh, you should, but you go to bed early.
: Oh, okay, maybe you can see it.

hive_lesson_quiz.question: 1) What does she put on her toast?
2) What does he do on Saturday?
3) What does she do on the Sunday night?
4) What is his favorite show about?
5) When does she go to bed?

hive_text_custom.text: Here are some basic ways to use verbs.

hive_grammar.point: Questions
Affirmative
Negative
Negative Contraction
Yes / No Questions

hive_text_custom.text: Yes, I do. / Yes, I eat at home.
No, I don't. / No, I don't eat at home.

hive_lesson.title: 04 Colors
hive_lesson.description: Two people discuss colors and things with them.

hive_text_custom.text: : Hey, Todd. Let's talk about colors.
: The ocean is blue. The sky is blue. During the day, the sky is blue. And my eyes are blue.
: Oh, mine too. What is red?
: Red. Let's see. Well, tomatoes are red. Strawberries are red, and ...
: Well, lots of vegetables are green. Lettuce is green. Cabbage is green or purple. And asparagus is green.
: Asparagus, right. Also, grass is green.
: Well, lemons are yellow. The sun is yellow, sometimes, or orange.
: Also, sometimes the sun is orange. Oranges are orange.
: Of course. Carrots are orange. What is black?
: Sometimes dirt is black. The night sky is black.
: Right. And your shirt is black.
: Yes. I like my black shirt.
: Vanilla Ice Cream is white. The snow is white.
: Clouds are white. And sometimes clouds are black.
: Yes, when it's going to rain.
: Some flowers are pink. Cotton candy is pink.
: Yeah. A lot of candy is pink, sometimes.
: Now, sometimes women's clothing is pink.
: Or men's. Do you like pink shirts?
: I don't usually wear pink shirts. What about you?
: I don't like pink shirts. I don't like pink, actually.
: Yeah, I love orange. It's so bright. What about you?
: I have three. I like the same. I know I like green. I love green, I love blue, I love purple.
: Right. I don't like orange, I don't like yellow, and I don't like pink.
: You don't like the warm colors.
: Yes. Bright colors, not so much.
: What about red? Do you like red?
: I don't especially like red. I like red poppies, a type of flower.
: But I don't like to wear red.
: Yeah, me too. Do you dislike any colors?
: Actually, I don't like brown. I think it's a boring color.
: Yeah, that's true. But often dogs are brown and I love dogs.
: I also like dogs, so a brown dog is okay. But a brown shirt, no, thank you.

hive_lesson_quiz.question: 1) What does he say is blue?
2) What does he say is green?
3) What does she say is yellow?
4) What does she say is white?
5) What does she say is pink?

hive_grammar.point: Subject + Verb + Object
Subject + Verb + Complement (Adjective)
Subject + Verb + Preposition + Noun
What + noun + do + subject + verb
Wh + do + subject + verb ++ ?
Do + subject + verb ++ ?

hive_text_custom.text: : Hey Todd, what is your hometown?
: Oh, nice. Is your town beautiful?
: Yes. San Francisco is very beautiful. It has a nice view of the ocean.
: Sounds nice. Is your town clean?
: It's pretty clean. Sometimes, it's dirty. Some places are dirty, but usually, the city is clean.
: No, it's not too dangerous. Sometimes, we have crime, but it's safe.
: Yes. San Francisco is very expensive. Everything is expensive. Food is expensive. Housing is expensive. Shopping is expensive. Everything.
: Oh, really? Is San Francisco famous?
Yes. It's very famous. In America, it's famous for its bridge. We have the Golden Gate Bridge. It's the world's most famous bridge, I think.
: I know that bridge. Is your town hot?
: Never. San Francisco is never hot. It's never super cold, but it's never hot. It's always warm or cool.
: Sounds great. Is San Francisco interesting?
: I think so. It's a very interesting city. We have people from everywhere, and we have good food. We have nature nearby, and we have interesting buildings.
: Wow. I'd like to go there.
: Ooh, you should. What about your city? What's your city?
: Ooh, Chicago. Chicago. Is your city beautiful?
: Yes. It's very beautiful, with lots of tall buildings and a big lake.
: Some parts of Chicago are clean, and other parts are a little dirty.
: How about dangerous? Is Chicago dangerous?
: Similarly, some parts are dangerous and some parts are safe.
: Yeah. San Francisco is the same. I think every American city is the same.
: Most places are safe, but some places are dangerous.
: Yes. Because it's such a big city, almost everything is expensive.
: I think so, a little similar.
: It can be hot in the summer. Usually July or August, it gets hot sometimes.
: Yes, of course. Chicago is very interesting. We have many museums, and things to do, and we also have nature. At the lake, you can go and enjoy a day on the beach.
: It's not by the ocean. It's by a really big lake called Lake Michigan. What about San Francisco? Is it by the ocean?
: Yeah, San Francisco is on the ocean. It's on the Pacific Ocean.
: o we have really nice beaches.
: I do, but the beaches in San Francisco are a little cold.
: In Los Angeles, they're warm, but Los Angeles is not interesting, and it's expensive, and it's not beautiful, so I don't like Los Angeles.
: So we should stick with San Francisco.

hive_lesson_quiz.question: 1) Is his city clean?

answers: c) No, it is very safe
hive_lesson_quiz.question: 2) Is his city dangerous?
3) Is his city expensive?
4) What is expensive about her city?
5) What is interesting about her city?

hive_text_custom.text: Adjectives are words that describe things.

hive_grammar.point: Point 1: Adjectives can go after a 'be' verbs.
Point 2: Adjectives can go before a noun.
Point 3: You can put adjectives together.

hive_lesson.title: 06 Days of the week
hive_lesson.description: Two people talk about their week.

hive_text_custom.text: : So, Meg, are you busy? Do you have a busy week?
: Yes. I usually have a busy week.
: Yeah, me too. So what day is your busiest day?
: On Thursday, I have to work from early in the morning until around 6:00 p.m. I have to teach classes. And then after that, I need to do my shopping at the supermarket.
: Okay. I do my shopping on Saturday.
: What else do you do on Saturday?
: On Saturday, I do all my boring activities.
: I do my shopping. I do my laundry. I run errands. I clean my apartment. I do boring stuff because on Sunday, I like to have fun.
: What do you like to do on Sunday?
: On Sunday, I often go hiking or I go to the park or I go to the beach. I go to the beach almost every Sunday.
: Yeah, the beach is beautiful. Nobody is there. It's really nice.
: How about you? What do you do on Sunday?
: On Sunday, I always go to church in the morning, and sometimes I'll have lunch with friends after church.
: And then, I usually clean as well, Sunday evening before the new week starts.
: Now, do you work Monday through Friday?
: Yes, I work every weekday. What about you?
: I work Monday, Tuesday, Thursday, Friday. I don't work Wednesday.
: Oh, what's your schedule like on Wednesdays?
: On Wednesdays, I usually stay at home and I relax. Sometimes, I go shopping. Sometimes, I go to the park. Sometimes, I prepare lessons because I'm a teacher.
: So, sometimes you do a little work on Wednesdays?
: Yes, but I do work at my house.
: I never go to school on Wednesday.
: Because it's a day off. So, how about Monday? Are you busy on Monday?
: I'm usually busy on Monday because my schedule is similar to Thursday, so I have to teach class until around 6:00 p.m.
: Yeah, Mondays are busy for me too. Mondays are busy. Thursdays also are busy. Tuesday and Friday are not so busy.
: Your schedule sounds a little similar to mine.
: What about activities? Do you do any activities during the week?
: During the week, if I have free time, sometimes I will watch a TV show or a movie and I also go to Japanese language class.
: Yeah, so sometimes I have homework so I have to do my Japanese language homeworks some nights. What about you?
: I play futsal on Tuesday nights. Every Tuesday, I play futsal with my friends for two hours and that's fun. And then, sometimes on Friday, I meet my friends for dinner.
: And I also like sports so I usually watch sports on TV on Monday.
: What sports do you usually watch on Monday?

: I watch everything. I watch baseball. I watch basketball. I watch American football and I watch soccer. So I come home and I watch a video of a game from Saturday or Sunday. I don't watch sports on Saturday or Sunday. I watch the video later on Monday night.
: Yeah. Usually, I don't check the internet, so I don't know the score.
: Well, it sounds like you have a busy schedule.

hive_lesson_quiz.question: 1) On what day is she busy?
2) What day does he go shopping?
3) What does she do on Sunday?
4) What days does he work?
5) What does does she do in her free time?

hive_grammar.point: Point 1: Spell names of the week with a capital letter.
Point 2: In spoken English, speakers often do not say the preposition on.

hive_text_custom.text: I will see you on Sunday.

hive_grammar.point: Point 3: We use different prepositions for some parts of the day, either in or at.
Point 4: When you combine a day of the week and a part of the day, you do need a preposition, except with noon and midnight. The time of day goes after the day.

hive_text_custom.text: I will see you Monday night.
I will see you Friday at noon.

hive_grammar.point: Point 5: The weekend is Saturday and Sunday, and the Weekdays are Monday thru Friday.

hive_lesson.title: 07 Nationaliteis and Languages
hive_lesson.description: Two people discuss the languages and places.

hive_text_custom.text: : So, Abidemi, let's talk about languages.
: You are from Nigeria and Nigeria has many languages, correct?
: How many languages can you speak?
: I would say that I can speak one language very well.
: And that would be English. But, I speak other languages fairly well. Yoruba, which is a Nigerian language, French, and a little bit of Japanese as well.
: You are Canadian also, and in Canada, students study French, correct?
: Do you speak French often in Canada?
: While I was living there I spoke it a lot more, yes.
: I love French. I love learning languages.

: French, I think, is very hard for some people, myself included, because the pronunciation of some words is very different than the pronunciation of American English. I think it's funny that there are some words in French that look exactly the same as words in English but we pronounce them completely differently. For example, I will say the word in English, and you say the same word in French. Okay?
: Right, so that is so interesting. Again, impossible.
: And they're spelled the same, correct?
: I have never thought of it like that before, Todd, but you're right. They look the same but the pronunciations are different.
: I think it's a trick because we see the word, and we know how to say it one way, but we have to say it a different way.
: We just can't do that well.
: Yoruba. How do you say, "How are you?" In Yoruba.
: Have you ever taught that language?
: No, never. I don't think too many people want to learn it outside of Nigeria.
: I think, in the future, more people will want to learn unique languages.
: What language do you want to learn in the future?

: I have many that, if I had more time, I would like to learn. I'm interested in Japanese, of course. I live in Japan now, so I would like to speak it better. I would also like to learn Mandarin, Russian, Hausa, another Nigerian language, Spanish, and maybe a couple of others.

: Yeah, there's so many languages I want to learn. I want to learn Spanish too. I can speak some Thai and Japanese because I lived as a teacher in both countries. But, I want to learn a language that has the same alphabet. I can read Thai but not very well. I can read Japanese but not very well. I want to learn a language where it's easy to read and see what the word is. In Thai, you can't do that. In Japanese, you can't do that.
: I know what you mean. It would make it easier to learn the language.
: But in Russian, you can't do that.
: That's true, but they have alphabets that are the same. You just have to decode them.
: A little bit, yeah. We have the phrase, it's all Greek to me, which means you have no idea. Anyway, thanks a lot, Abidemi.

hive_lesson_quiz.question: 1) How many languages does she speak?
2) What is similar about French and English?
3) What does she teach him to say in Yoruba?
4) What language does she want to learn?
5) What language does he want to learn?

hive_grammar.point: Point 1: The names of countries, languages, and people from a country begin with a capital letter.
Point 2: The adjective form of a country can be used to describe people, languages, and items.

hive_text_custom.text: She is Italian, but does not speak Italian.
We bought a Japanese car in Japan.

hive_grammar.point: Point 3: There are some patterns in English for nationalities but there are many exceptions. It is best to just remember them case-by-case.

hive_lesson.title: 08 Sentence Patterns
hive_lesson.description: Two people discuss their daily routines.

hive_text_custom.text: : So Natalie, what is a typical day for you? For example, what is a typical morning?
: Well, I wake up at about 7.00 a.m.
: Yes, I really am a morning person.
: I think you are a morning person. I'm not a morning person at all.
: Well, I don't actually get out of bed until about 7.30.
: Okay, so what do you do?
: Well, I play on my phone, I check my emails, I check Facebook, and I read the news.
: Do you eat breakfast at home?
: I usually prepare breakfast at home, yeah.
: Oh, just the simple stuff, eggs, bacon, sausages, sometimes I'll have toast.
: Do you drink coffee or tea?
: No, I don't like coffee or tea.
: Actually, I like hot chocolate in the morning.
: Yeah, I like hot chocolate too. So what about your day?
: Well, I'm a teacher. I teach at a school. Lessons start at about 9.00 a.m. and we have lunch at noon.
: How many classes do you have in the morning?
: Each class lasts an hour, so I have three classes.
: Do you eat lunch at school?
: Yes, we have a huge canteen.
: The food is great and it's so much fun eating with the students too.
: Is the food cheap or expensive?
: It's pretty cheap. I'd say maybe $3 for lunch.
: Yeah, and for that you get a lot of food.
: What do you do in the afternoon?
: In the afternoon I have more lessons, usually taking me till about 4.00 p.m.
: Oh and do you have big classes?
: Yes, so I teach English, that means I teach the whole year, so I have really big classes. We have about 200 students at the school.
: What about the evening? What do you do in the evening?

: When I get home I'm usually really tired, so I get changed into my pajamas and I watch TV for about two hours. After that, I'll maybe have some dinner, maybe get a pizza and then read a book or play on my phone again.
: What do you watch on TV?
: I really like watching Korean drama.
: I know, the characters are so much fun.
: A little bit but I think it's a little bit boring. I prefer American pop.
: Oh so you like Korean dramas and American music?
: That's right. I also like game shows.
: Well actually my favorite one is Busted, and that's also Korean.
: Okay, I need to see that. So when do you go to bed?
: Most nights I go to bed at around 10.00 p.m. but at the weekend, sometimes it's later, maybe around midnight.
: Well I think you have an interesting and long day.
: That's right, I'm usually very tired.

hive_lesson_quiz.question: 1) When does she get out of bed?
2) What does she do in the morning in bed?
3) What does she like to eat in the morning?
4) What does she drink in the morning?
5) What does she do in the evening?

hive_grammar.point: Point 1: A common sentence pattern in Engish is S.V.O which means sbject, verb, object.

hive_text_custom.text: My town has a big park.
They play tennis once a week.

hive_grammar.point: Point 2: WH questions usually follow this pattern: WH + Auxiliary + S + O + ?

hive_text_custom.text: What do you do at your job?
Where did you buy that shirt?

hive_grammar.point: Point 3: Yes / No questions use the same pattern withouth the WH word: Auxiliary + S + O + ?

hive_text_custom.text: Do you get much snow in your town?

hive_grammar.point: Point 4: Yes / No questions often have short form answers.

hive_lesson.title: 09 Subject Pronouns
hive_lesson.description: Two people try to guess some famous people.

hive_text_custom.text: : Can you guess the famous person?
: Okay, person number one. She is American, she is a singer, she is young, she is about 25 years old, and now she is very famous. Her hair is blonde and she is very cute and very pretty.
: Okay, so the next person is also very famous, he is from Argentina. He is a soccer player, he is very good at sports, and he is on a team in Spain.
: Yeah, he is very good. He is a little short, but he is quick, he is very fast.
: Hmm. I don't watch soccer so much, but is it Cristiano Ronaldi?
: Ooh, I don't know who he is.
: Oh no. Ronaldo is the rival of Lionel Messi.
: Okay, so 1-1. Alright, ready? Next one. This person is from Hong Kong, he is older, he is my age, about 50, maybe older. He is good at martial arts, he is in many movies.
: Oh, also he is funny, he is very funny.
: Okay, so now let's switch. You ask me.
: Okay. This person is a woman, she is American, and she is a very famous singer in the United States and in the world. She is married to a very famous rapper. Do you know who she is?
: Okay, are you ready for the next person?
: He is a Jamaican and he runs really fast.
: Okay, he is fast, he's from Jamaica.
: Mm-hmm (affirmative), and he is so fast he joined the Olympics and won many times.
: Is he a gold medal winner?
: He is a gold medal winner.

hive_lesson_quiz.question: 1) Who is the first person?
2) Who is the second person?
3) Who is the third person?
4) Who does she talk about first?
5) Who famous man does she talk about?

hive_grammar.point: Point 1: Subject pronouns take the place of a person or person's name.

hive_text_custom.text: Sally is a farmer. She works outside.
Sally is a farmer. She works outside.
Sally is a farmer. She works outside.
Sally is a farmer. She works outside.
Bob is a doctor. He works at a hospital.
Bob is a doctor. He works at a hospital.
Bob is a doctor. He works at a hospital.
Bob is a doctor. He works at a hospital.
Bob and Sally are married. They have one child.
Bob and Sally are married. They have one child.
Bob and Sally are married. They have one child.
Bob and Sally are married. They have one child.
Bob and Sally are married. They have one child.
Bob and Sally are married. They have one child.
They have a house. It is really big.
They have a house. It is really big.
They have a house. It is really big.
They have a house. It is really big.
We like them. You will too!
We like them. You will too!
We like them. You will too!
We like them. You will too!

hive_grammar.point: Point 2: The first person subject pronoun (I, we) refers to the speaker. It can be singular (S) or plural (P).
Point 3: The second person subject pronoun (you) refers to the listener. It can be singular (S) or plural (P).
Point 4: The third person subject pronoun (he, she, it, they) refers a person, people, thing or things.

hive_text_custom.text: I like Bob. He is nice.
I like Bob. He is nice.
I like Bob. He is nice.
I also like Sue. She is funny.
I also like Sue. She is funny.
I also like Sue. She is funny.
Bob and Sue are married. They have one child.
Bob and Sue are married. They have one child.
Bob and Sue are married. They have one child.
Bob and Sue are married. They have one child.
Bob and Sue are married. They have one child.
Bob and Sue are married. They have one child.
They have a house. It is really big and nice.
They have a house. It is really big and nice.
They have a house. It is really big and nice.
They have a house. It is really big and nice.
They have a house. It is really big and nice.
They have two cars. They rarely drive them.
They have two cars. They rarely drive them.
They have two cars. They rarely drive them.
They have two cars. They rarely drive them.
They have two cars. They rarely drive them.
: So Todd, you live in Japan. Do you see your family often?
: Yes. I see them often. I see them usually once a year, but I write to them often, and I call them sometimes.
: Okay. And when you see them, do you go to the United States to visit them, or do they come to Japan?
: I go to America, and then everyone goes to my mom's house, and everybody meets me at my mom's house, which is nice. I see my sister, and we talk a lot, and it's good.
: Yes. She misses me and I miss her a lot, so it's very nice to see her, and also, I miss my dad. I miss him a lot, so I'm always happy to see him.
: Nice. What about your sister? When you're in the United States, do you have some activities you like to do together?
: Yeah, sometimes we do stuff together. Maybe I will meet her at a café, or I will go shopping with her, so we do something fun each time I go back.
: Also, when I go home, I see my best friend, and that's always nice. I usually meet him for dinner, and of course I call him, and it's always nice to see my best friend. How about your family?
: Well, since I live in Japan, I also call them and write them, but usually, we only Skype about once a month.
: Oh. So, who do you Skype with the most, your mom or your dad?
: I Skype the most with my father, because he wakes up very early, so his time and his schedule match my schedule, so it is easy for us to Skype.
: Do you call him or does he call you?
: I usually call him, but sometimes he calls me. Usually, if he calls me, it's because I haven't called in a long time.
: So sometimes, you make him mad.
: You have a brother too, right?
: I do have a brother, and I call him less frequently, because he is so busy with his job, so we speak about once or twice a month, by messages or by phone.
: Oh, that's nice. Do you follow your family on social media?
: It is a really easy way to keep in contact with them.
: Yeah, I agree. What about other social media? Do you use Twitter?
: No. I don't use Twitter, and I don't use other social media either, only Facebook.
: Ah, that's good, I think. Too much is too bad.
: I agree, but I do love Facebook, because I can speak with my brother, and my mother, and my father anytime.
: So, with Facebook, do you check it every day?
: I do check it every day. Maybe it's a bad habit, but I do like to check it every day. Do you check your Facebook every day?
: Not every day. I check it maybe three times a week.

: Yeah, I don't use it much, and I don't use it on my phone. 
Shantel: Oh. That's a good idea. 
Todd: Yeah. I like my free time. 
Shantel: Do you use other social media, such as Twitter or Instagram? 
Todd: I do use Twitter, but I don't use it on my phone. I only use it on the computer. 
Shantel: Okay. What about Instagram? 
Todd: Oh, I don't use it at all. Do you use it? 
Shantel: No, I don't use it. 
Todd: Oh, that's right. You only use Facebook. 
Shantel: I only use Facebook. 
Todd: Oh, interesting. Well, that's nice that we can talk to our family on Skype and Facebook, because Japan is so far from America. 
Shantel: Yes, and I think they are very happy too. 
Todd: Yeah, I think they are happy.

hive_lesson_quiz.question: 1) How often does he see his family?
2) Where does he usually meet them?
3) Who does he meet?
4) Who does she meet?
5) What does she use to contact family?

hive_grammar.point: Point 1: Subject pronouns take the place of a person or noun.

hive_text_custom.text: Did you see Sue? I just saw her.
Did you see Sue? I just saw her.
Did you see Sue? I just saw her.
Did you see Sue? I just saw her.
Did you see Sue? I just saw her.
Where is Tony? Did you see him?
Where is Tony? Did you see him?
Where is Tony? Did you see him?
Where is Tony? Did you see him?
Where is Tony? Did you see him?
I like your jacket. Where did you buy it?
I like your jacket. Where did you buy it?
I like your jacket. Where did you buy it?
I like your jacket. Where did you buy it?
I like your jacket. Where did you buy it?
My students are funny. I like them so much.
My students are funny. I like them so much.
My students are funny. I like them so much.
My students are funny. I like them so much.
These shoes are dirty. I need to clean them.
These shoes are dirty. I need to clean them.
These shoes are dirty. I need to clean them.
These shoes are dirty. I need to clean them.

hive_grammar.point: Point 2: The first person object pronoun (me, us) refers to the speaker. It can be singular (S) or plural (P).

hive_text_custom.text: (P) Did you see us on TV?
(P) Did you see us on TV?
(P) Did you see us on TV?

hive_grammar.point: Point 3: The second person object pronoun (you) refers to the listener. It can be singular (S) or plural (P).
Point 4: The third person subject pronoun (him, her, it, them) refers a person, people, thing or things.

hive_text_custom.text: I like Bob. I see him every day.
I like Bob. I see him every day.
I like Bob. I see him every day.
I like Bob. I see him every day.
I like Bob. I see him every day.
I also like Sue. I often see her at the gym.
I also like Sue. I often see her at the gym.
I also like Sue. I often see her at the gym.
I also like Sue. I often see her at the gym.
I also like Sue. I often see her at the gym.
Bob and Sue eat out often. I join them sometimes.
Bob and Sue eat out often. I join them sometimes.
Bob and Sue eat out often. I join them sometimes.
Bob and Sue eat out often. I join them sometimes.
Bob and Sue eat out often. I join them sometimes.
Bob and Sue eat out often. I join them sometimes.
They have a horse. They let me ride it.
They have a horse. They let me ride it.
They have a horse. They let me ride it.
They have a horse. They let me ride it.
They have a horse. They let me ride it.
They have two cars. They never use them.
They have two cars. They never use them.
They have two cars. They never use them.
They have two cars. They never use them.
They have two cars. They never use them.

hive_lesson.title: 11 Demonstrative Pronouns
hive_lesson.description: Two people compare clothes and their watches.

hive_text_custom.text: : Hey, Natalie, I like your outfit. It looks really cute.
: So, that shirt looks expensive. Did it cost a lot?
: Oh, this one? Yeah. It was about $50.
: I know. It's an American brand.
: Ah. Do they have that shirt in different colors?
: Yes, so I actually have this top in six colors.
: I have it in purple, blue, red, gray, white, and black. Actually, I have two black ones, so that's seven.
: You have two shirts in black? Why?
: Well, black is such a good color to wear. It matches everything.
: Yeah. So true, so true. What about your pants? Those pants are pretty cool too.
: Oh, these? Yeah. These were much cheaper than the tops. I bought these in San Francisco. They cost about $40.
: Ooh. Those are cheap. That's a good price.
: It is, and I only have one pair of these.
: And your shoes? Did you buy those shoes in San Francisco too?
: No, I didn't buy these in San Francisco. These, I bought online.
: Yes. These sandals are really hard to find, so I had to buy them through Amazon.
: Oh, I like Amazon. I buy lots of things on Amazon. For example, I bought this watch on Amazon.
: Well, this watch was really cheap. This watch only cost about $20.
: Yeah, but I have two watches, and I also bought a nice, gold watch on Amazon. That watch was very expensive. It cost $200.

: Whoa, $200 on a watch? I think my watch only cost maybe $70, but I really like this watch. It's an Apple Watch. I bought it in Malaysia. I've had it for about two years now, but I think now that I have an Apple Watch, I'll always have Apple Watches.
: Yeah, that is a nice watch. I want an Apple Watch too.
: Yeah, they're so cool. I spend so much time on my phone, and the watch works really well with my phone. I definitely recommend it.

: Yeah, I like this cheap watch, because if it rains, or if I play sports, or if I am traveling, I can take my cheap watch, because this watch is not important. I can break it. I can lose it. I can do anything. But my gold watch, that watch is expensive, so I keep it at home. I only wear it on nice occasions.

: Oh, well it's nice to have something a little more expensive, but my watch can tell me what the weather's like, my watch can tell me how many calories I've burned, and my watch can tell me what the time is anywhere in the world.
: You know, I think I need to get a watch like that.

hive_lesson_quiz.question: 1) How many shirts does she have of the same top?
2) What clothing items does she discuss?
3) How much were the pants?
4) Where did she buy the pants?
4) Who has a smart watch?

hive_grammar.point: Point 1: Use this and that for singular nouns. This refers to objects closer to the speaker.

hive_text_custom.text: I like this shirt. (close to speaker)
I like this shirt. (close to speaker)
I like this shirt. (close to speaker)
I don't like that shirt. (away from speaker)
I don't like that shirt. (away from speaker)
I don't like that shirt. (away from speaker)
Look at that car! (away from speaker)
Look at that car! (away from speaker)
Look at that car! (away from speaker)
This bike is nice! (close to speaker)
This bike is nice! (close to speaker)

hive_grammar.point: Point 2: Use these and those for plural nouns. This refers to objects closer to the speaker.

hive_text_custom.text: No, those books over there are my books.
No, those books over there are my books.
No, those books over there are my books.

hive_grammar.point: Point 3: Speakers sometimes do not mention the noun if the object is clear.
Point 4: After using demonstratives, we often use pronouns (subject/object) to reference them.

hive_text_custom.text: Yes, I like them. They are cool.
Yes, I like them. They are cool.
Yes, I like them. They are cool.
Yes, I like them. They are cool.
Yes, I like them. They are cool.
It's a coffee maker. I use it a lot.
It's a coffee maker. I use it a lot.
It's a coffee maker. I use it a lot.
It's a coffee maker. I use it a lot.
: Hey, Todd. Let's talk about countries.
: You live in Japan right now.
: Yes. That's right. I live in Japan. I teach English in Japan.
: Oh, cool. Tell me, what's expensive in Japan?
: Well, Japan is a very, very expensive country. Transportation is very expensive in Japan. Train tickets are expensive. Also, sometimes, taxis are expensive. Even buses are expensive.
: Wait. You don't have a car in Japan?
: Actually, I do have a car. That's funny because in Japan, cars are very cheap. Cars are cheap but taxis are expensive. It's crazy.
: That's so weird. In the U.K., where I'm from, taxis are really cheap, but to have your own car, it's so expensive.
: I'm really interested in Japan. Tell me, what's beautiful in Japan?

: Oh, Japan has lots of beautiful things. The temples are very, very beautiful. The nature and the scenery are beautiful as well. There are beautiful forests, beautiful lakes, beautiful beaches, and even beautiful buildings.
: Cool. What is difficult about living in Japan?
: Well, Japanese is difficult. Reading Japanese is very difficult. Writing Japanese is difficult because Kanji is difficult. Kanji is the Japanese character.
: How many characters are there in Kanji?
: There are about 2,000 characters. It's difficult to learn all the characters, all the Kanji. It's very hard.
: Wow. I bet that's really tough. Tell me, what's fun about living in Japan?

: Well, there's many things that are fun about Japan. The people are fun. They're very nice. Teaching English in Japan is fun. The students are very nice. Day-to-day life in Japan is fun and exciting. I live in Japan, but you live in Thailand. What about Thailand? What is expensive in Thailand?

: Well, Thailand is a really cheap place to live, but some restaurants are really expensive. For example, if you go to a American restaurant, that's very expensive, but if you go to street food carts, they're really cheap.
: Yeah. The street food is very delicious.
: Speaking of food, what Thai foods are really delicious?

: My favorites are Pad Ka Prao. This is pork. It's spicy with rice and chili. I also like Tom Yum Goong. This is like a soup, but it's very spicy. It usually comes with shrimp and mushrooms, ginger. I usually get some rice.
: Yeah. I love Tom Yum Goong. It's really, really good. What is difficult about living in Thailand?

: I think that transport is a very difficult part of living in Thailand. If you have a car, the roads are very busy. It takes a long time to get anywhere in the city. I usually use the subway or the skytrain system, but these get really busy in the morning. When I'm taking the train to work, there's usually so many people on the train at the same time. Sometimes, it actually makes me late for work.
: Yeah. The trains in Japan are really busy too. What is fun about life in Thailand?
: Good question. I really like the people here. Thai people are so friendly. They're very fun. They always like to hang out.
: Yeah. Thailand sounds like a nice place to live.
: Yeah. It's a great place to live, actually.

hive_lesson_quiz.question: 1) What is expensive in Japan?
2) What is cheap in the UK?
3) What is difficult in Japan?
4) She says the roads are _____ in Thailand.
5)  The trains in Japan and Thailand are _____ .

hive_grammar.point: Point 1: Use adjectives after a BE verb to describe things.
Point 2: Use adjectives before nouns to describe things.
Point 3:Use words like very, really, and so to add intensity.
Point 4: Use not before the adjective and after the BE verb for negative statements.

hive_text_custom.text: His house is not very big.
His house is not very big.
His house is not very big.
They are not happy with their jobs.
They are not happy with their jobs.
They are not happy with their jobs.

hive_lesson.title: 13 Months and Holidays
hive_lesson.description: Meg and Todd talk about American holidays.

hive_text_custom.text: : Hey Todd, let's talk about months and American holidays.
: Great. What holiday is in January?
: Well, on January 1st, we have New Year's Day.
: In February, we have Valentine's Day on February 14th.
: Oh, sorry. What about March? What holiday is in March?
: Yes. Do you usually celebrate St. Patrick's Day?
: I do. I love green. Green is my favorite color.
: April has April fool's Day, but that's not a holiday.
: Not really, but it's still fun to celebrate on April 1st.
: Right. Oh, usually Easter is in April.
: Usually yes, but the day changes every year.
: What about in May? What holidays are in May?
: In May, I think a lot of countries have a holiday on May 1st, but America doesn't have a holiday on May 1st, but we do like to have fun celebrations for Cinco de Mayo, May 5th.
: Right. What do you usually do for Cinco de Mayo?
: I hear that in Mexico they don't celebrate Cinco de Mayo.
: Yeah, funny. I actually heard that St. Patrick's Day also is not popular in Ireland.
: In June, we have the first day of summer.
The longest day of the year.
: In July, in America of course, we have July 4th, Independence Day.
: Yeah. What do you do on July 4th, Independence Day?
: Usually, I would have a barbecue with friends and family and watch fireworks.
: What about August? Is there a holiday in August?
: I can't think of a holiday in August, but my brother's birthday is August 15th.
: Do you know of any holidays in August?
: I don't, but usually school is out in August, so for the whole month there's no school.
: Yeah, vacation time. What about September?
: Well, September has Labor Day, but I don't remember the day. Is it September 1st?
: I think it changes every year.
: I think so. Let's see, after September, what holiday is in October?
: Oh, what day is your birthday.
: Okay, so what holiday is in November?
: Yes. Actually, Thanksgiving is my favorite holiday.
: I know, I change, I changed it.
: It changes, like Easter. It's on the third Thursday.
: Is it the third or the fourth Thursday?
: You're right. It's on the fourth Thursday of every November.
: Right. How do you usually celebrate Thanksgiving?
: I have dinner with my family-
: Well, December has Christmas, which is December 25th.
We also have New Year's Eve, which is December 31st.
: Yeah, really good holidays. I like it because you get lots of time off work or school.
: Yeah, it's good to spend time with friends and family.
: Yes. You could give me a gift.
: My favorite holiday is actually Halloween.
: Okay, I change again, me too.

hive_lesson_quiz.question: 1) When is Valentine's Day?
2) When is Saint Patrick's Day?
3) When is Independence Day in America?
4) What day is popular in May?
4) When is Labor Day?

hive_grammar.point: Point 1: There are twelve months in the year.
Point 2: Always start months with a capital letter.
Point 3: Use the preposition 'in' for months and seasons.

hive_text_custom.text: I will be back in June.
I have a vacation in December.

hive_grammar.point: Point 4: There are four seasons in most English speaking countries.

hive_lesson.title: 14 Ordinals
hive_lesson.description: Two teachers talk about their school schedule.

hive_text_custom.text: : Hello. Are you the new teacher?
: I am, yes. My name's Natalie. What's your name?
: I'm Todd. Nice to meet you.
: So do I. I teach Math first period, too.
: Oh, cool. After that, for second period, I teach French.
: That's great. Well, I speak some Japanese, so I teach Japanese second period.
: Oh, that's so cool. I wish I spoke Japanese.
: Yeah, but my Japanese is not very good.
: But I'm the only teacher that speaks Japanese, so I teach Japanese.
: Maybe you could teach me one day.
: Maybe, but I don't know much. How about third period? What do you teach third period?
: Ah. I teach English, too. Our schedules are very similar.
: I know, although it is my first day. I'm a little nervous.
: What about the afternoon schedule? What do you teach fourth period?
: Fourth period, I think I have Physics.
: Yeah. I love Physics. Do you teach Physics?
: No, I don't teach Physics, but I teach Math. I teach Math fourth period.
: Oh. What do you teach in fifth period?
: In fifth period, that's the sports period. I am the cross-country coach.
: Oh. I have sports, too, but I'm the coach for swimming.
: Oh, really? Are you a good swimmer?
: I think I'm a really good swimmer. How about you?
: I can swim, but I'm not a good swimmer. I like running.
: Oh, I hate running. How far do you run?
: Well, for the class, usually we run 5K every day.
: Wow! 5K. Sixth period, I hear that's our teaching hours.
: Yeah. Sixth period, we are in the classroom, but the students are free. They can do what they want. But students can come to class and ask questions.
: Oh, cool. Do lots of students come and ask questions?
: Yeah. Some students come, but not too many.
: Well, this is your first day and your first week, so maybe the job will be a little crazy. But I think after your second or third week, the job will be very, very easy.
: I hope so. I'm really excited to meet the students. They seem great.
: Oh, I think the students will like you a lot.
: Oh, I hope so, too. Maybe if you have some time, you could give me a tour of the school?

hive_lesson_quiz.question: 1) What does she teach first period?
2) What does she teach second period?
3) What does she teach Third period?
4) What does she teach fourth period?
5) What does she coach fifth period?

hive_grammar.point: Point 1: Ordinals are numbers that show the order things appear or occur.
Point 2: Most ordinals are just the number + th
Point 3: The numbers 1 - 3 have special ordinals.
Point 4: The numbers 11 and 12 have specials spellings that do not follow the normal rule.
Point 5: Numbers that end in -y change to -ieth.

hive_lesson.title: 15 Telling Time
hive_lesson.description: Two people talk about when they do things.

hive_text_custom.text: : First, when do you get up?
: Yeah, I get up early too. I don't get up at 7:30, but I get up at 8:00.
: Oh, well, sometimes I get up at 8:00. Maybe at the weekend.
: Yeah. Actually, I always wake up at 6:00. I wake up very early, but I don't get out of bed. I wake up. I have some water, and then I sleep some more. I sleep two more hours.
: Sometimes I wake up at 7:30 and I play on my phone for maybe an hour.
: I read that it's not good to check your phone in bed. I never check my phone in bed.
: What about breakfast? When do you eat breakfast?
: I usually eat breakfast at around 8:30, but sometimes I don't have breakfast.
: I usually have breakfast right away. I wake up at 8:00 or I get out of bed at 8:00 and then I eat something at 8:15. I eat something as soon as I get up.
: Oh. No. I usually have to wait before I can eat.
: Well, I always eat and I always have coffee very early.
: Do you have coffee every day?
: Every day. I have three cups of coffee. I have one cup of coffee around 8:00. I have another cup of coffee around 10:00 and then I have my last cup of coffee around 2:00 or 3:00.
: Yeah. My office is by a café and the café has really good coffee. I love their café mochas.
: Oh, I really don't like the taste of coffee, but I do love a hot chocolate.
:  Oh, I hear you. When do you start your day at work or school?
: Well, I work as a teacher, so I start at 9:00 a.m.
: Yeah, it's okay. I work for a few hours in the morning and lunch comes by really quickly. How about you? When does your day start?
: Well, I have two jobs. Now, I make websites and I work at an office. I start at 12:00, so noon. I start my day late. I finish working at 8:00 or 9:00 at night.
: I wish I started work at 12:00, but I don't think I'd enjoy working so late.

: Oh, it's great. I love it, because there's no traffic at noon when I go to work and there's less traffic at night when I come home. I finish at 9:00 and the train is not crowded and it's really nice.
: How long does it take to get to work?
: It takes 15 minutes by train. If the weather is nice, on nice sunny days I walk to work, it takes one hour and I walk home, it takes another hour.
: It is nice. I like to walk to work and I like to walk home. I work at night, so I eat dinner really late. I eat dinner at 10:00 and that's very late and a little unhealthy. When do you eat dinner?
: Well, yeah, 10:00 p.m. is really late. I'm usually in bed at that time. I usually have dinner I'd say maybe 7:30 p.m.
: Wow. You have dinner before I finish work.
: I know, but if I don't eat at that time, I get really cranky.
: Yeah, most nights, but at the weekend, I usually go to bed later. I'd say midnight, sometimes 1:00 a.m. or 2:00 a.m.
: Wow. That's interesting, because on workdays, Monday to Friday, I go to bed late, but on the weekend, my days off, I go to bed early.
: Yeah. On Saturday night and Sunday night, I go to bed at 10:00, but Monday to Friday I work, I go to bed at 12:00 or 1:00.
: Why get up early at the weekend?
: I don't know. I actually don't like staying up late, but I do it for my job. It's strange I guess. On the weekends, some people like to sleep in. On the weekends, I like to go to bed early.
: Oh, my. At the weekend, I love to have a lie in bed. Sometimes I stay in bed all day and watch movies.
: Oh, you know, I'm guilty of that too. I do that also.

hive_lesson_quiz.question: 1) Who gets up at seven-thirty?
2) Who wakes up first?
3) When does he finish work
4) When does she go to bed?
5) Who goes to bed early on the weekend?

hive_grammar.point: Point 1: You can use o'clock at the top of the hour, but often it is not spoken.

hive_text_custom.text: It is six o'clock. - It is six.
It is eight o'clock. - It is eight.
It is twelve o'clock. - It is twelve.
It is two o'clock. - It is two.

hive_grammar.point: Point 2: Twelve o'clock has two special names. Noon for daytime and midnight for night time.
Point 3: For time 30 minutes past the hour, you can use the term "half past".
Point 4: For time 15 minutes past the hour, you can use the term "a quarter past".
Point 5: For time 45 minutes past the hour, you can use the term "a quarter to/till".
